requestFieldValues.label: Summary
requestFieldValues.value: Help obtain list of all access groups for team reference

requestFieldValues.label: Description
requestFieldValues.value:
Given that IBM Cloud manages access to resources via Access Groups and Resource Groups, it makes sense that a P2 team member told me that access requests that come through this Jira to grant SCBN team members access to their environments should specify an Access Group.

Many squads in SCBN have a set of known/existing Access Groups that they store in their internal documentation.  We now have a new squad that was just formed and they are asking how they would get a list of applicable Access Groups that they could ask for permission to.

This seems like a platform-level issue, as I do not know how the Access Groups are created or managed within IBM Cloud.  The teams come to *me* to validate whether their access should be approved, therefore, I need to know whether they are asking for the right Access Group, and therefore, *I need a list of all Access Groups applicable to SCBN*.



Thanks\!

requestFieldValues.label: Summary
requestFieldValues.value: Configure instana to scrape kafka metrics

requestFieldValues.label: Description
requestFieldValues.value:
Hi P2PaaS team,

We need to export prometheus metrics from EIS Alerts services by p2paas-instana as per [https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/instana-observability/current?topic=apis-prometheus|https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/instana-observability/current?topic=apis-prometheus].
Need to add below in p2paas-instana configmap (under configuration.yaml: ):-

{noformat}com.instana.plugin.prometheus:
  enabled: true
  podConnectTimeout: 120000
  podReadTimeout: 120000
  customMetricSources:
  - url: '/actuator/prometheus'
    metricNameIncludeRegex: 'kafka_topic_partition_current_offset|kafka_consumergroup_lag_sum'
  - url: '/stats/prometheus'
    metricNameIncludeRegex: 'kafka_topic_partition_current_offset|kafka_consumergroup_lag_sum'{noformat}

{{geodelivery.intelligence-airbusds.com }}(airbus’s SFTP server)

requestFieldValues.label: Summary
requestFieldValues.value: Look at opening Turbonomic for writes to non-prod clusters

requestFieldValues.label: Description
requestFieldValues.value:
We have had a number of sessions with the Turbonomic team recently. We are interested in going ahead with testing Turbonomic’s ability to not only detect issues, but to actually make the changes (scale in/out, change resource req and limits, etc.). Turbonomic will be faster to see issues and react to them than a human.



This ticket ultimately is to enable updates from Turbonomic to the clusters, but to start, we can use this to discuss any security or other concerns of this type of interaction.



The non-prod clusters:

* inventory-viz-np-dal
* inventory-viz-sip-rls-np-dal

One thing that will help build confidence that our new releases have not regressed any functionality, is to run the same synthetics that we run in our production clusters.

To that end, the ask is to expose the public ingress IP in this cluster, but only to Instana so that the synthetics can reach it. This most likely involves figuring out what Instana IP address ranges (or domain name) to use and apply to the firewall.

Alternatively, we can investigate a POP (point-of-presence) Instana server in our cluster, but we would prefer not to go that route.

Note that the instana instance in this case is the non-prod one. (i.e. [omsnp-ibmaiapps.instana.io|http://omsnp-ibmaiapps.instana.io])

Thanks

Vijeya was checking the logs of instana agent when he noticed this issue in pilot.

Here are some samples:



“VM_ARGS= -Dkafka.sasl.username=ss-sharedservices-np-wdc-user-v3 -Dkafka.sasl.password=<removed> -Dkafka.security.ssl.truststore.location=/opt/truststore/infohub_ssl.truststore -Dkafka.security.ssl.truststore.password=<removed> -Delasticsearch.username=elastic -Delasticsearch.password=<removed> -XX:+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError -XX:HeapDumpPath=/tmp/heap-dump.hprof -Dkafka.security.ssl.truststore.password.vault=<removed> --add-opens java.base/java.util=ALL-UNNAMED -Xmx1207959532 “

requestFieldValues.label: Summary
requestFieldValues.value: Review and update reserve compute resources on worker nodes in non-prod clusters

requestFieldValues.label: Description
requestFieldValues.value:
When we have spikey workloads that push our worker nodes to 100% CPU, they become unresponsive. The pods themselves get throttled (understandable), but then some pods get into a restart loop (kong) and generally everything on the node starts to become unresponsive and call failures show up. It seems like the base OS services and the k8s kublet/proxy/etc. get CPU starved causing everything to break down. I did some digging and I think there is a node configuration that can help. Here is a {{describe node}} for one of our default nodes:


{code:none}Capacity:
  cpu:                16
  ephemeral-storage:  308505408Ki
  hugepages-1Gi:      0
  hugepages-2Mi:      0
  memory:             65636296Ki
  pods:               160
Allocatable:
  cpu:                15880m
  ephemeral-storage:  282397320572
  hugepages-1Gi:      0
  hugepages-2Mi:      0
  memory:             59877320Ki
  pods:               160{code}

Right now, there is only *120 millicores* allocated to the OS and k8s system components when under full load. I think this is as least part of the issue. Memory allocatable seems reasonable, it's just the CPU that seems extremely low. I would have expected anywhere from 0.5 to 1 CPU to be the buffer to ensure the OS/k8s system can still function under heavy pod load. 



Main Kubernetes documentation: [https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/reserve-compute-resources/|https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/reserve-compute-resources/]



Can this be investigated? Specifically decreasing the CPU Allocatable?  This can be tested in non-prod clusters first to see if there are any negative effects, and we can try with a load to try to prove responsiveness:

* inventory-viz-np-dal
* inventory-viz-sip-rls-np-dal



Here’s an example when a worker node was at 100% CPU:

[https://instana.io/s/6TZ-lsdPTqq39m-4lCogSQ|https://instana.io/s/6TZ-lsdPTqq39m-4lCogSQ]

requestFieldValues.label: Summary
requestFieldValues.value: Config hub Application penetration testing issue: Secure Client-Initiated Renegotiation

requestFieldValues.label: Description
requestFieldValues.value:
SCBN Configuration Hub(CH) application was subjected to internal penetration testing in Q2 2021 and the following issue was reported. This issue applies to all 6 clusters(as following) of CH in non-prod and production.

– scbn-config-hub-np-dal
– scbn-config-hub-np-wdc
– scbn-config-hub-pr-dal
– scbn-config-hub-pr-wdc
– app-services-pr-ams
– app-services-pr-fra

We created a PSIRT [PVR0290016|https://ibm.service-now.com/sn_vul_product_records.do?sys_id=be0af4f91b923450e74b7599cc4bcbf3] for this issue in CH which is due by 12/29/2011 and hence request to get this issue addressed before the due date. Below are more details on the issue.

*Description:*
Client initiated Renegotiation is enabled. Although the SSL supports secure renegotiation, it is recommended to disable the renegotiation on the server side to prevent any attacks using this feature.

The remote service encrypts traffic using TLS / SSL but allows a client to securely renegotiate the connection after the initial handshake. An unauthenticated, remote attacker may be able to leverage
this issue to inject an arbitrary amount of plaintext into the beginning of the application protocol stream, which could facilitate man-in-the-middle attacks if the service assumes that the sessions
before and after renegotiation are from the same 'client' and merges them at the application layer.

Denial of Service (DoS): Establishing a secure SSL connection requires more processing power on the server, around 15 times, than on the client. An attacker can exploit this processing-power property
along with renegotiation to trigger hundreds of handshakes in the same TCP connection; an assault can bring down a 30Gb-link server using only a laptop and DSL connection.

*Reference:*
https://blog.qualys.com/ssllabs/2011/10/31/tls-renegotiation-and-denial-of-service-attacks
https://blogs.mcafee.com/mcafee-labs/tips-securing-ssl-renegotiation/

*Related snapshot(s):*
Please refer to the attached snapshot

Affected IP(s) and Port:
10.209.61.26:636
10.65.227.105:31536
10.65.227.46:31536
10.65.227.231:31536
10.65.227.204:31536
10.187.167.230:30223
10.65.227.75:31536
10.65.227.93:31536

_Note:_ These is the worker node IP and may have changed if P2PaaS performed an upgrade in last 6 months.

*Fix Recommendation:*
Disable the client initiated renegotiation if the feature is not required.

We can take several steps to mitigate the threat of renegotiation attacks. Renegotiation is not required by the majority of sites. Disable SSL renegotiation support on the server.
If disabling renegotiation is not possible due to business needs such as ecommerce, then allow only secure renegotiation and limit the number of SSL handshakes, or upgrade server resources by adding
products like an SSL accelerator. Do not support insecure renegotiation.

requestFieldValues.label: Summary
requestFieldValues.value: Configure instana to scrape kafka metrics

requestFieldValues.label: Description
requestFieldValues.value:
Hi P2PaaS team,

We need to export prometheus metrics from EIS Alerts services by p2paas-instana as per [https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/instana-observability/current?topic=apis-prometheus|https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/instana-observability/current?topic=apis-prometheus].
Need to add below in p2paas-instana configmap (under configuration.yaml: ):-

{noformat}com.instana.plugin.prometheus:
  enabled: true
  podConnectTimeout: 120000
  podReadTimeout: 120000
  customMetricSources:
  - url: '/actuator/prometheus'
    metricNameIncludeRegex: 'kafka_topic_partition_current_offset|kafka_consumergroup_lag_sum'
  - url: '/stats/prometheus'
    metricNameIncludeRegex: 'kafka_topic_partition_current_offset|kafka_consumergroup_lag_sum'{noformat}

Post that need restart instana for non-prod environment.

We created a PSIRT [PVR0290010|https://ibm.service-now.com/sn_vul_product_records.do?sys_id=37f5f8311b923450e74b7599cc4bcbd4] for this issue in CH which is due by 12/29/2011 and hence request to get this issue addressed before the due date. Below are more details on the issue.

*Description:*
LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) is a software protocol for enabling anyone to locate organizations, individuals, and other resources such as files and devices in a network, whether on the
public Internet or on a corporate intranet. LDAP is a "lightweight" (smaller amount of code) version of Directory Access Protocol (DAP).
During active reconnaissance, default LDAP port 389 was found to be open and allows anonymous binds. Anonymous binds (or NULL binds) permits any user to anonymously access information from the LDAP directory.
Anonymous binds (or NULL binds) permits an attacker to anonymously access information from the LDAP directory and use it for his further attacks.

*Reference:*
NONE

*Related snapshot(s):*
Please refer to the attached snapshots

Affected IP(s) and Port:
10.209.61.26:389
10.209.61.26:636

_Note:_ These are the worker node IPs and may have changed if P2PaaS performed an upgrade in last 6 months.

*Fix Recommendation:*
If you are not using this service, it is recommended to disable it. Otherwise, it is recommended to disable anonymous binds.
